content.webTitle: Chelsea youngsters will get chances in Premier League with FA Cup a priority

fields.headline: Chelsea youngsters will get chances in Premier League with FA Cup a priority
fields.bodyText: Guus Hiddink has vowed to name his strongest team against Manchester City on Sunday afternoon but intimated that younger members of his Chelsea squad, such as Bertrand Traoré, will be afforded increased playing time in future Premier League games with the club too far off the European places and safe from relegation. While Manchester City’s manager, Manuel Pellegrini, will play a weakened side on account of Wednesday’s Champions League trip to Dynamo Kyiv, Hiddink says the FA Cup is a priority and will make “hardly any” changes. The Dutchman clarified that he would not hesitate in using his young players if required but confirmed the likes of Traoré and Ruben Loftus-Cheek, who have featured only sporadically, are set to gain more experience in league matches towards the end of the season. “Putting one of the youngsters in depends on the demands of the FA Cup, but I don’t hesitate putting them in if needed,” Hiddink said. “We have games still to go in the Premier League where there might be more options. I don’t make any guarantees to players but there might be more opportunities for them in the near future. Sometimes you cannot always stick to your principles but they will get some chances.” Traoré scored his first senior goal in the previous round against MK Dons and struck his first in the league last weekend in the rout of Newcastle. While the player had considered going on loan before deciding to bide his time at Stamford Bridge, Hiddink is glad he remained, saying the 20-year-old striker is “improving tremendously”. Hiddink added: “Although he’s not playing, his character is very optimistic, He’s always coming in with a smile, whether he’s playing or not. When a player comes into the Premier League, saying ‘I don’t want to go on loan, I want to make my progress here’, and when they get their first goal – and it was a beautiful goal, a typical striker’s goal which I like very much – it was a tremendous joy for him. “He was desperate to stay. We were thinking about sending him on loan, yes or no. We talked about that but he would love to be with us for the rest of the season and he has made progress.”
